title: Self-Healing Concrete Uses Bacteria
description: A 60-second lesson on Self-Healing Concrete Uses Bacteria.

hook.text: Scientists put bacteria in concrete that wake when cracks form, eat nutrients, and excrete limestone to seal them.

buildup.text: Concrete cracks from temperature shifts, load stress, and settling. Water enters, corrodes rebar, and speeds failure.

discovery.text: Bacillus survive dormant 200+ years in concrete. When a crack lets in water and oxygen, they wake and make calcite.

twist.text: Bacteria eat calcium lactate pellets in the mix and precipitate calcium carbonateâ€”the same mineral found in limestone.

climax.text: Self-healing concrete could save billions in global repairs. Crack upkeep on bridges and tunnels costs $100B+ yearly.

punchline.text: Living concrete that heals its own wounds.

quiz.question: How do bacteria seal cracks in self-healing concrete?
options: They consume nutrients and excrete limestone (calcium carbonate) that fills the cracks
They produce a sticky biofilm that glues the crack surfaces together
They expand when activated, physically pushing the crack closed
